content.title: Pension to Unmarried Poor, Incapacitated Women of Age 50 years and above
content.department: Social Welfare and Women Empowerment Department
content.beneficiary: Unmarried Poor, Incapacitated Women of Age 50 years and above
content.details: The 'Pension to Unmarried Poor, Incapacitated Women of age 50 years and above' is a state scheme launched by the Social Welfare and Women Empowerment Department, Government of Tamil Nadu. The scheme aims to provide a pension of ₹1,000/- to unmarried, poor, incapacitated women of age 50 years and above. The destitute women are also provided with one free saree during Pongal and Deepavali, and free rice in the Anganwadi Centres.
benefits: One free saree during Pongal and Deepavali
2kg/month of free rice for those taking nutritious meals
4kg/month of free rice for those not taking nutritious meals
eligibility: The applicant should be a woman.
The applicant's age should be 50 years and above.
The applicant's fixed assets should not exceed ₹1,00,000/-.
content.application_process: Online - via CSCs. The applicant should gather copies of the necessary documents needed to apply for the concerned scheme, visit the nearest Common Service Center (CSC) for biometric verification, fill in the application form, and request a receipt or acknowledgement.
documents_required: Smart Ration Card or Any Address Proof
Any Identity Proof (Voter ID Card, Passport, PAN Card, Driving License)

faqs.question: I am physically unable to collect the free rice from the Anganwadi center. Can someone else collect it on my behalf?
faqs.answer: Yes, you can authorize a family member or trusted individual to collect the rice on your behalf. You might need to complete an authorization form.

faqs.question: Can I choose the color or design of the free saree?
faqs.answer: No, the scheme typically provides pre-selected colors and designs for the free sarees distributed during Pongal and Deepavali.

faqs.question: Will the application process cost me anything?
faqs.answer: No, applying for the scheme is completely free. You shouldn't pay any fees at the CSC or to any individual for processing your application.

faqs.question: Is there a specific deadline to apply for the scheme?
faqs.answer: No, the Pension to Unmarried Poor, Incapacitated Women of age 50 years and above scheme is an ongoing initiative, and you can apply at any time.

faqs.question: I am 50 years old and recently separated from my husband. Can I apply right away?
faqs.answer: Yes, as long as you meet the other eligibility criteria (destitute, unmarried), you can apply for the scheme even if you just separated from your husband.

faqs.question: I live in a remote area. Are there alternative ways to apply besides visiting the CSC?
faqs.answer: You can inquire with the Social Welfare Department about potential mobile camps or designated application centers closer to your location.

faqs.question: Do I need to renew my application every year to continue receiving the benefits?
faqs.answer: No, once approved, you don't need to reapply every year. However, you might need to update your information periodically, as instructed by the authorities.

faqs.question: I don't have access to a computer or the internet at home. How can I apply?
faqs.answer: You can still apply by visiting the nearest CSC. They have the necessary facilities to complete the application process on your behalf.

faqs.question: Can I apply for the scheme online without visiting the CSC?
faqs.answer: Currently, applying for the scheme requires visiting the nearest Common Service Center (CSC). They will assist you with the application process, including biometric verification and document upload.

faqs.question: I am a 48-year-old widowed woman. Can I apply for the scheme now?
faqs.answer: No, unfortunately, the minimum age requirement to apply for the scheme is 50 years old. You can apply once you reach that age.

faqs.question: I am a victim of domestic violence and separated from my husband. Am I eligible to apply?
faqs.answer: Yes, if you are legally separated from your husband, you would be considered 'unmarried' and potentially eligible for the scheme, provided you meet the other criteria.

faqs.question: Is the pension amount credited directly to my bank account, or can I receive it another way?
faqs.answer: The pension is typically deposited directly into your bank account. You'll provide your bank details during the application process.
